bibl.title: Letter from Carlos E. Finlay to Philip Showalter Hench, December 22, 1941

div1.p: Finlay disagrees with some points in Hench's speech, given during the unveiling of Cornwell's painting, "The Conquerors of Yellow Fever."

div1.head: Letter from Carlos E. Finlay to Philip Showalter Hench, December 22, 1941
div1.opener:
DR. C. E. FINLAY
LINEA NUMERO 710
TELEFONO F-4730
VEDADO, HABANA
CUBA
December 22 1941
Dr. Philip S. Hench
Mayo Clinic
Rochester Minn.
Dear Dr. Hench
div1.p:
Many thanks for your letter of November 22nd with the Reprint of
your address at the unveiling of Cornwell's painting.

There are some points in your address with which I disagree. One is
the repeated statement that my father did not produce a single case of experi-
mental yellow fever, based mostly on the length of the so-called “external
incubation” which was supposed to require twelve days but which recent
work by the Rockefeller workers have confirmed to vary from 4 to 18 days
according to the outside temperature, time required for the virus to reach
the salivary glands and in the mosquito to be infective through the bite,
whereas if the mosquito be crushed and its contents injected it is found
infective from the moment of its ingestion, destroying the phallacy that
that the supposed parasite of yellow fever had to spend a phase of its
existence in the body of the mosquito like that of malaria. Another is
your version of Lazear's inoculation which is at variance not only with
the official account but with the account written by Agramonte to my father;
it also presupposes ethics in his co-officers at loggerheads with those
we have always been proud to consider in connection with the U.S.A. and
whollly unnecessary as life insurances are payable even in cases of delibe-
rate suicide once a certain length of time has ellapsed, Lazear is known to
have received a negative inoculation some time prior to the time of his
last infection and to have made several inoculation experiments unknown
to the remainder of the commission, two of which according to Agramonte

were positive, the details of which may possibly have existed in the
notes found in his little notebook. The importance of Lazear's case
according to the official report is that it was evidently produced
by a shortly incubated mosquito found within the net from which he was
collecting mosquito for future experimental work.

Wishing you the best success in your efforts to raise money for
the purchase of the San Jose farm and for a coming Happy New Year
